short-container-title: Acta Crystallogr C Cryst Struct Commun
Acta Crystallogr Sect C Struct Chem
Acta Cryst Sect C Struct Chem
Acta Crystallogr Sect C Cryst Struct Commun
items.abstract: <jats:p>A cinnamamide (3-phenylprop-2-enamide) core is present in many pharmacologically active compounds. We report three new crystal structures of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-substituted cinnamamide derivatives which were screened for anticonvulsant activity, namely (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>S</jats:italic>)-(2<jats:italic>E</jats:italic>)-<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-(2-hydroxypropyl)-3-phenylprop-2-enamide, C<jats:sub>12</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>15</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>), (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>S</jats:italic>)-(2<jats:italic>E</jats:italic>)-<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-(1-hydroxybutan-2-yl)-3-phenylprop-2-enamide, C<jats:sub>13</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>17</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>), and (2<jats:italic>E</jats:italic>)-1-(4-hydroxypiperidin-1-yl)-3-phenylprop-2-en-1-one, C<jats:sub>14</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>17</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>). Compounds (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) and (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) crystallize in the <jats:italic>Pbca</jats:italic> space group with one molecule in the asymmetric unit, whereas compound (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) crystallizes in the <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>2<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>c</jats:italic> space group with two molecules in the asymmetric unit. All the crystal structures are stabilized by intermolecular O—H...O hydrogen bonds and additionally by N—H...O hydrogen bonds in the structures of (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) and (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>). The investigated compounds possess fragments that are considered as beneficial for anticonvulsant activity. The conformations of these compounds were analyzed in comparison with the characteristic features of the proposed pharmacophore model of anticonvulsants active in the maximal electroshock test, <jats:italic>i.e.</jats:italic> a phenyl ring or other hydrophobic unit, an electron-donor atom and a hydrogen-bond acceptor/donor domain. In the reported series, two calculated distances fitted the reference model, while the third did not. Structure–activity analysis suggests that anticonvulsant properties may be related to the N-atom substituent. It is beneficial to combine an electron-donor atom (<jats:italic>e.g.</jats:italic> an O atom) with an H atom in the substituent to ensure appropriate interactions with the molecular target. We analyzed the intermolecular interactions in order to find an appropriate spatial arrangement of the important features responsible for anticonvulsant activity.</jats:p>
title: Crystallographic studies of cinnamamide derivatives as a means of searching for anticonvulsant activity

reference.unstructured: Bruker (2004). COLLECT. Bruker AXS Inc., Madison, Wisconsin, USA.
Otwinowski, Z. & Minor, W. (1997). Methods in Enzymology, Vol. 276, Macromolecular Crystallography, Part A, edited by C. W. Carter Jr & R. M. Sweet, pp. 307-326. New York: Academic Press.

Stables, J. P. & Kupferberg, H. J. (1997). The NIH anticonvulsant drug development (ADD) program: preclinical anticonvulsant screening project, in Molecular and Cellular Targets for Antiepileptic Drugs, edited by G. Avanzini, P. Tanganelli & M. Avoli, pp. 191-198. London: John Libbey & Co. Ltd.
WHO (2015). WHO Media Centre, Fact sheet No. 999, May 2015.

title: Synthesis and Evaluation of Anticonvulsant Activity of Some N-[(4-Chlor- 2-methylphenoxy)ethyl]- and N-[(4-Chlor-2-methylphenoxy)acetyl]aminoalkanols

short-container-title: Acta Crystallogr C Cryst Struct Commun
Acta Crystallogr Sect C Struct Chem
Acta Cryst Sect C Struct Chem
Acta Crystallogr Sect C Cryst Struct Commun
items.abstract: <jats:p>A number of cinnamamide derivatives possess anticonvulsant activity due to the presence of a number of important pharmacophore elements in their structures. In order to study the correlations between anticonvulsant activity and molecular structure, the crystal structures of three new cinnamamide derivatives with proven anticonvulsant activity were determined by X-ray diffraction, namely (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>S</jats:italic>)-(2<jats:italic>E</jats:italic>)-<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-(2-hydroxybutyl)-3-phenylprop-2-enamide–water (3/1), C<jats:sub>13</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>17</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>·0.33H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O, (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>), (2<jats:italic>E</jats:italic>)-<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-(1-hydroxy-2-methylpropan-2-yl)-3-phenylprop-2-enamide, C<jats:sub>13</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>17</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>), and (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>S</jats:italic>)-(2<jats:italic>E</jats:italic>)-<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-(1-hydroxy-3-methyl-butan-2-yl)-3-phenylprop-2-enamide, C<jats:sub>14</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>19</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>). Compound (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) crystallizes in the space group <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>-1 with three molecules in the asymmetric unit, whereas compounds (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) and (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) crystallize in the space group <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>2<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>c</jats:italic> with one and two molecules, respectively, in their asymmetric units. The carbonyl group of (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) is engaged in an intramolecular hydrogen bond with the hydroxy group. This type of interaction is observed for the first time in these kinds of derivatives. A disorder of the substituent at the N atom occurs in the crystal structures of (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) and (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>). The crystal packing of all three structures is dominated by a network of O—H...O and N—H...O hydrogen bonds, and leads to the formation of chains and/or rings. Furthermore, the crystal structures are stabilized by numerous C—H...O contacts. We analyzed the molecular structures and intermolecular interactions in order to propose a pharmacophore model for cinnamamide derivatives.</jats:p>
title: Cinnamamide pharmacophore for anticonvulsant activity: evidence from crystallographic studies

Acta Crystallogr Sect C Cryst Struct Commun
items.abstract:
<jats:p>Aminoalkanol and aroxyalkyl derivatives are known as potential anticonvulsants. Two new salts, namely bis{(<jats:italic>R,S</jats:italic>)-<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-[2-(2,6-dimethylphenoxy)ethyl]-1-hydroxypropan-2-aminium} succinate (<jats:bold>1s</jats:bold>), C<jats:sub>13</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>22</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>
                  <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>·0.5C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>
                  <jats:sup>2−</jats:sup>, and bis{(<jats:italic>S</jats:italic>)-(+)-<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>-[2-(2,6-dimethylphenoxy)ethyl]-1-hydroxypropan-2-aminium} succinate (<jats:bold>2s</jats:bold>), C<jats:sub>13</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>22</jats:sub>NO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>
                  <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>·0.5C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>
                  <jats:sup>2−</jats:sup>, have been prepared and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The N atoms are protonated by proton transfer from succinic acid. Salt <jats:bold>1s</jats:bold> crystallizes in the space group <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>2<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> with one cation and half an anion in the asymmetric unit across an inversion centre, while (<jats:bold>2s</jats:bold>) crystallizes in the space group <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>2<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> with four cations and two anions in the asymmetric unit. The hydroxy group of the cation of <jats:bold>1s</jats:bold> is observed in two <jats:italic>R</jats:italic>/<jats:italic>S</jats:italic> disorder positions. The crystals of these two salts display similar supramolecular architectures (<jats:italic>i.e.</jats:italic> two-dimensional networks), built mainly by intermolecular N<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>—H...O<jats:sup>δ−</jats:sup> and O—H...O<jats:sup>δ−</jats:sup> hydrogen bonds, where `δ−' represents a partial charge. The succinate anions are engaged in hydrogen bonds, not only with protonated N atoms, but also with hydroxy groups.</jats:p>
title: Supramolecular architectures of succinates of 1-hydroxypropan-2-aminium derivatives
